name: methyl_propyl_sulfide
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: 1,3-propanedisulfide has a melting point of -109.4 degrees Celsius. The basic unit for comparison can be ethane, which has a melting point of -172.0 degrees Celsius. The introduction of the methyl group (–CH3) and the propyl group (–C(C)C) in place of hydrogen atoms increases the molecular weight and size, which raises the melting point. However, the sulfur within the sulfide group (–S–) increases the molecular weight and van der Waals forces, which raises the melting point. The methyl group introduces a hydrogen bonding potential, which lowers the melting point. The propyl group introduces more rigidity, which raises the melting point.
